Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on outdated data from 1997 and does not provide any recent statistics to back it up.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Americans work the longest hours of any people around the world without considering more recent data or alternative explanations.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the United States ranked eighth in terms of the annual number of hours actually worked per person in the latest available data from 2008.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it relies on outdated information and does not consider more recent data that may provide a different perspective.
Understate: The claim may understate the actual hours worked by people in countries such as Greece, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, and Mexico, which ranked higher in terms of the annual number of hours worked per person in the latest available data.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for why Americans may perceive themselves as working the longest hours, such as cultural or societal factors.
